dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room looking into the hall. The programme directo ANDREYEV (45) leans back in his chair. Eyes closed, he “conducts” the music with a cheap fountain pen. A technician, SERGEI, keeps an eye on dials and buttons. There's a clock and a portrait of Stalin on the wall. The phone rings. Grudgingly, Andreyev answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (snappy ) Radio Moscow. Director Andreyev. What is it? He suddenly tenses, gesturing at the technician to turn d the music. Sergei watches him, munching on an apple.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 17 minutes?..... He gropes manically for a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 5..eleeeee The pen doesn't work. He shakes it - no good.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he's not) .-Yes, I'm writing it down.. He smacks the apple out of Sergei’s hand and gets him to over a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- 9?.. Was it a 9, like 'fine' or a 5 like.... (gestures to Sergei)

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: --hive?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Hello?... Hello? They've gone. He hangs up. He's in a state.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: Who was it?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 2.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: The Secretariat of the... General Secretariat. The General Secretariat's.. the General Secretary’s Secretaria...

dialogues.speaker: SERGEIL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) .--Stalin?! Sergei turns away. He's not getting involved.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: I'm to ring back in exactly 17 minutes. 17 minutes from the start or the end? How long did I talk for? HOW LONG? INT. CONCERT HALL —- AUDITORIUM - NIGHT 3 Some of the audience are lost in the music. A NERVOUS MAN glances at an NKVD GUARD looking at him. Trying to hide his panic, the nervous man looks away then back to the guard... who waves coyly. A woman sat next to waves back. The nervous man heaves a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on a large portrait of Stalin: handsome, strong, sl dark hair. We pan down to see the real STALIN - frail, ol grey hair - at his desk. His frail fingers search through lists of names as the Mozart concerto plays on his radio. Humble decor: a few chairs, a desk, a small bed. A short, stocky man with cold eyes behind a set of pince- stands on the other side of the desk. This is BERIA.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I put Shteyman on the list. The writer. I know you like his stuff, but... Stalin thinks for a moment, then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: No. Keep him on.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (points at the next name) Shteyman 2, his wife. Stalin gives a tiny shrug meaning ‘yes.’  20 May 2016 Draft 10 3.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Shteyman 3. His brother.

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: On. Better to be sure. Beyond Beria, through a doorway, a bulky, balding middle- man - KHRUSHCHEV, 59 - is entertaining two other bulky me MALENKOV - 57, - and MOLOTOV - 70. Khrushchev is miming an amusing war incident; people ina panic not knowing what to do with a live grenade.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: .-they were all jumping around like drunken whores..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the auditorium, we see the window of the director's office with the figure of Andreyev pacing in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev is miming a man with a grenade in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: He had this look like: (muffled) ‘There’s a grenade in my mouth'. Stalin signs the lists and hands them to Beria.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I'll have these dispatched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreyev stares at the clock. Time has passed; the music moved on to a new movement.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: “It is the greatest honour...’ (he bows) He can’t see me bow, idiot.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: Er, Comrade Director? It's 10.27. Andreyev rushes for the phone, banging his hi painfully on the table. He grabs the phone and dials. The music finishes and we hear applause. He gestures frantica to the technician to turn the loudspeaker off. Someone answers the phone.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 4.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Hello?... YES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalin is on the phone, with the applause playing on the radio and the others laughing drunkenly in the other room

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: This is Stalin. In the background, Khrushchev is continuing his story.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: So I said “You'll have to enunciate”. Then- He mimes the grenade going off, to uproarious laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The applause is loud. Andreyev rushes to a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (stammering) Comrade... General... How are things? Sorry... Hold on... He gets in the cupboard. The phone cord only just reaches

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry again...

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I want a recording of tonight's performance. I'll send someone to pick it up. Stalin hangs up. He notices that one sheet of the list of names has been left behind. Beria comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (picking up sheet) Ah. Don’t want them to miss the party, do we? He heads back out.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria divides the lists between some SENIOR NKVD OFFICERS including DELOV.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (pointing to the list) Shoot her before him but make sure he sees it. And this one. Kill him, take him to his church, dump him in the pulpit. He's pleased with the idea. He heads back to the dacha. INT. CONCERT HALL - DIRECTOR’S OFFICE/CORRIDOR - NIGHT 12 Some MUSICIANS sweep into the Director’s office, others a at the entrance out into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 1
dialogues.text: .--she said “I only wear them at the weekend”! Laughter. Surprise as Andreyev steps out of the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Was the concerto recorded? Was it recorded?! Say “yes” to me.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: Um... No. Andreyev can barely breathe.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Stop them leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreyev storms along corridor and down some stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Break their legs. Not that, but anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreyev reaches the foyer and fights against the flowing crowd and in to the hall were some musicians are packing

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Encore! Encore the whole bloody thing! Don’t test me, you fucking idiots. Sorry. You're very talented. But please go back on.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 6. INT. CONCERT HALL —- AUDITORIUM - NIGHT 15 The audience are leaving, among them the NERVOUS MAN. He' keeping his eye on the NKVD man by the exit. Andreyev rushes to the stage, and bangs a cymbal with a flute, knocking aside music stands to get to the front.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (to Security) Lock the doors! Lock the doors! (to everyone else) Don't worry, no-one is going to get killed. But I do need you to stay! Everyone - musicians, audience - look at him. The nervous is sweating, terrified. Security guards block the doors. NKVD man remains inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sparsely furnished dining room after a long night of drinking and eating. Stalin is just sitting down at one e filling his pipe with crumbled cigarette tobacco. Malenko tops up everyone's glass.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: You know, you put someone’s little finger in a glass of water when they’re asleep? They wet themselves.

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: What next? Place a bar of chocolate in their pocket, they’1l shit their pants?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: It’s biology, chief. We did it to Polnikov in Stalingrad. Beria joins them, picking up a tomato from the table.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Potato doing his war stories again? (looking at his watch, then to Molotov) WELL before midnight. Pay up. Molotov gets out some cash. They've clearly had a bet.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: You're bankrupting me, Nikita. This is a capitalist conspiracy.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 7.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What became of that old dog Polnikov?

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: You want to know where fucking Polnikov is? You want to GO there? Malenkov knows he shouldn't have asked. Beria puts his arm round Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I love that grenade story. Oh, is there one in your pocket? Khrushchev pulls a squashed tomato from his pocket. Beria the others laugh. Stalin too.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (laughs, camping it up) I die for the Motherland! MUSIC: dramatic orchestral. Under the music, everything slows down. In slow motion, we see Khrushchev and Beria laughing at e other, like two braying animals. Khrushchev tries to wipe hand on Beria's jacket, generating more laughter. We can hear, at a quarter of the speed, Beria and Khrushchev cal each other 'Potato' and 'Tomato' but it sounds like grunt We see under Beria, the caption "Lavrenti BERIA. Head of Security Forces". And under Khrushchev, his caption: "Nik KHRUSHCHEV, in charge of Agricultural Reform". MUSIC OUT - Back to normal speed. Malenkov takes another tomato from the table, desperate t in on the joke.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Take THIS, you bastards! He mimes pulling a grenade pin from it with his teeth. No doesn’t know where to take the joke. Puts the tomato down MALENKOV (CONT’D) Anyway...better get back to...

dialogues.speaker: STALIN
dialogues.text: Time for a cowboy movie. Who’s in my posse? Everyone tries to look excited.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 8.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Oh good, it's Stagecoach again.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Yee-hah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra are on stage. Half the audience remain. Security guards are at each door. Andreyev at the front o the stage. Maria is nearby at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: Half the audience have gone. The acoustic will be very dry.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Pull people in off the streets! Fat ones, so we won’t need so many! MUSICIAN 1, the orchestra’s joker, asserts himself.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 1
dialogues.text: I could call my wife? She'd... (indicates “fat”) .-."dampen the acoustic”. Laughter. Andreyev turns to the audience, trying to smile

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Comrades! A TRUMPETER plays a quick fanfare, prompting laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Comrades, shut up! I have great news! Wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 1
dialogues.text: (to Andreyev) Are you pregnant? The trumpeter parps. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Comrade Stalin... (shoots a look) ..-loved tonight's concerto and would like a recording of it right away which we don't have for some reason and trust me we will look into why that happened, but meanwhile... the concerto we just played will be played by us again... Now. Please. We will record it and applaud it.  18 19 20 21 20 May 2016 Draft 10 9. No smiling now. Some of the musicians start clapping, the the audience, security guards, a very relieved nervous ma everyone. It's a huge standing ovation, though you can ju make out someone dry-heaving. When it dies we hear Maria.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 1
dialogues.text: You cow hole bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars from Stalin's dacha fanning out from the main ca and off on different routes across the city. We see the list from the dacha in the hand of Delov. We stay with one car as it passes several black military- style trucks and vans. NKVD men in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black marias pull up. NKVD men and Delov get out and star fanning out towards the apartment blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan across windows. Despite terrible noises from below, n one light goes on. We think we see a slight stir in the d at one window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreyev hurries Maria up the concert hall and into his office. The conductor follows them in. Through the office window, we can see the orchestra and audience watching.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: You, Joan of Arc, you want to get killed?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh, like my father “got killed”? My brother? Like THAT? He sits her down in a chair.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 10.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: You want a family reunion in the mortuary?! The Conductor is in the background looking unwell.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I won't do it. You can't force me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (to the conductor) Should we get another pianist?

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: No, that's ridiculous. The sound would be entirely different. Even Stalin could...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: “Even”.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: (frozen in fear) No... I meant...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Even STALIN? Is this office bugged?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (trying to help out) Of course Comrade Stalin will be able to tell the difference. He's a great man, with a great ear for music.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Two great ears.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: The two greatest ears in the Soviet Union. Andreyev comes close to Maria, takes her hands, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maria Viniaminovna...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (of her fingers) Don’t crush the little workers. He lets go.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: You have to play.  22 20 May 2016 Draft 10 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: (to the unseen bug) I didn't mean what I said...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (to Conductor) So you said it then. (to Andreyev) As God is my witness, I won't do it. The Lord will see me through.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: 10000 roubles.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Done. Andreyev hurries Maria out into the corridor, followed by conductor - who faints, banging his head on a sand bucket

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who put that there? What brainless fucking fire safety FUCKER put that there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. Khrushchev, Beria, Malenkov and Molotov are watching a John Wayne western. Beyond them, Stalin stands by his desk, looking at papers Molotov has fallen asleep, with Malenkov next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: He gets shot off his horse. (guy gets shot off horse) Yup. Adios.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (loudly, so Stalin hears) Horses are shit, son! You should have commandeered a tank.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: You know we produced 5000 T-64 tanks last year?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: If I have to watch this fucking movie again, drive one over my head.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 12.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I can have that arranged. Ach, little sleep tonight. My men are bringing in lots of lost sheep...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Anyone we know on the list?

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (admonishing) Hey, we’re supposed to be watching Shitcoach. They look up to see if Stalin is listening.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (quieter) Any good ones?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: One of his guards. Says his wife gave him some slippers to wear so he wouldn't make any noise. The old man’s convinced it’s so he can creep up on him in his sleep and kill him.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Where will it end? Are we arresting anyone with feet? Malenkov laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Nikita. I’m having a man shot for “acquiring slippers”. Never joke about something so serious. Stalin comes towards them.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (loudly, to alert Molotov) Ah, you're just in time for the Red Indian attack. He does a loud, clumsy hand-over-mouth war cry. Molotov wakes and panics.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: He.. the horse.. I was.. thinking.. important.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: You were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: No. Focussed... on the soundtrack.  23 24 25 20 May 2016 Draft 10 13. He yawns, and we go into slow motion again. Dramatic MUSIC Again. Under Molotov, the caption: "Vyacheslav MOLOTOV. Foreign Secretary". Under Malenkov, laughing, is "Georgy MALENKOV. Deputy Gen Secretary". Back to normal speed.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Molotov) You'll soon have plenty of time to sleep, comrade. He turns to the others. A look of enigmatic menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men in nightshirts are marched out of doorways by NKVD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men and women in their nightclothes led into vans by NKVD

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MOSCOW APARTMENT —- ROOM - NIGHT 25 BORIS BRESNAVICH and MRS BRESNAVICH are asleep. There's a loud banging at the door. They switch on the light, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRESNAVICH
dialogues.text: Don't open. Don't open it!...

dialogues.speaker: BRESNAVICH
dialogues.text: They'll kick it down... Mrs Bresnavich goes to the window and sees A MAN being le away by NKVD OFFICERS. She starts to cry. Bresnavich has pulled on a dressing gown and slippers ove his pyjamas. The couple hug and kiss like people who know they may never see each other again.

dialogues.speaker: BRESNAVICH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you...  26 27 20 May 2016 Draft 10 14.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRESNAVICH
dialogues.text: (distraught) Oh my God, your things.... He clasps her hands.

dialogues.speaker: BRESNAVICH
dialogues.text: Say whatever you have to say to them. Say it. It doesn’t matter. Bresnavich heads to the hallway. Through adjoining window he sees another MAN being led away. Still the knocking. INT. MOSCOW APARTMENT —- HALLWAY - NIGHT 26 Bresnavich opens the door to a friendly-looking CONCERT DIRECTOR in a dinner suit. In the hallway, two people are being led away.

dialogues.speaker: CONCERT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Comrade. Deepest... (he bows) Radio Moscow requests your presence immediately. Please. You're Moscow’s finest and... nearest conductor. (a little desperate) We must hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria, Khrushchev, Molotov and Malenkov are walking toget to their limos, drunk, tired.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Nice work mentioning Polnikov. (Malenkov impression) "Whatever happened to Polnikov? And Trotsky, I liked him."

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: "I miss the tsar"...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What is this, the Malenkov Pogrom? I’m drunk. I can’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: A tip, Melanie. When you go home, get your wife to write down everything you think you said. Then in the morning you know what you're dealing with. Khrushchev’s Law!  28 20 May 2016 Draft 10 15.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Good night, comrades! Long live the Communist Party of Lenin-Stalin! Long live John Wayne and John Ford! Molotov drives off in his limo. He waves. They wave back.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (does throat cutting gesture) Goodbye, old friend. Goodbye forever. They all register the shock.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Yep. On the list. It would be simpler and cheaper if they just drove straight into a river. Sweet dreams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fuller now: some in overalls, one with a dirty brush beside more smartly dressed concert-goers. A BIG WOMAN ea pickled onions. Some are filing up to the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: (shouting at people on balcony) You... no, YOU! Yes, keep going along! Fill it up! The orchestra warm up. Andreyev starts clapping. The audience, ushers, Concert Director and security guards jo in. Andreyev wants it louder. The audience oblige. Maria enters, bows and takes her seat at the piano. Andreyev keeps the applause going as Bresnavitch enters w a conductor's baton, still in his dressing gown and slipp

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 2
dialogues.text: Shit. Was Chaplin busy?

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 3
dialogues.text: Bresnavich can't do Mozart! He has no feel for nuance.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN 2
dialogues.text: He’s in his dressing gown. I'd say “nuance” is fucked.  29 30 31 32 20 May 2016 Draft 10 16. Bresnavich turns to face the orchestra and loses a slippe He gropes for it with his foot as he taps his baton to be The orchestra starts playing, from the very beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN desperately "over-dressing" - putting layers of clo on top of each other. He grabs a roll of money and stuffs in his underwear. The door is kicked open to reveal NKVD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev slowly, drunkenly, taking off his clothes. His wife, NINA, sits on the bed taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I joked about the farmers. Stalin laughed. I joked about the navy. He didn’t laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria, yawning, strolls along, cleaning his pince-nez. Be him an NKVD guard, ILYIN walks with a crying WOMAN in her 20s.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I'll see you again in twenty minutes. Beria gestures to a cell door and the guard pushes her in Further back, another door opens and an unconscious priso is dragged out by 2 NKVD men. They lift the prisoner’s ha up and wave it at the other occupant in the cell - goodby

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back with Khrushchev and Nina.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I mentioned Polnikov.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You fool!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: No, I got away with it. Then Malenkov mentioned him again, Stalin hated that.  33 34 35 36 37 38 39 20 May 2016 Draft 10 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MATRONLY WOMAN desperately scrubs blood off stairs, cry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG MAN points some NKVD to the front door of a build with a distinctive design.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several people are brought out of the distinctive buildin NKVD and put in vans. One is a MIDDLE-AGED MAN, who clock the young man hiding in the shadows. He knows he's to bla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRIGHTENED PRISONER sits on a chair in the middle of th room, hands cuffed behind his back. A door opens and Beri comes in. He stands right behind the prisoner and massage his shoulders, whispering in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A serene Maria and sweating Bresnavich bring the concerto its conclusion. There's a brief silence - relief - then applause. The Big Woman is still eating pickled onions. INT. CONCERT HALL - DIRECTOR’S OFFICE - NIGHT 38 Andreyev jumps and grabs the recording.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEI
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we check it...? Andreyev is already running out with record.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: No time! If it’s screwed, so are you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back with Khrushchev and Nina.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Beria did the tomato-in-the-pocket thing. Arsehole. You'll have to clean the trousers. Then... slippers...  40 20 May 2016 Draft 10 18.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (looking for slippers) I think they're...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Shh! (swaying as he tries to get out of a trouser leg) Oh God, what was the slippers thing? Stalin’s slippers? Molotov’s? Fuck. WHAT DOES IT MEAN?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreyev manically pelts down the staircase towards the N men, brandishing the new record, followed by his staff.

dialogues.speaker: I HAVE IT
dialogues.text: He sees Pervak ahead, waiting. Andreyev slows to a walk, done his duty. The staff follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (more low key now) I have the recording. We needed to find a new... sleeve. He looks down at the sleeve. It's plain and white.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A white one. Because the other one was.. blue. It looked very... shit.

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: The delay has been logged.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: I’ve done my duty. Any “delay” is being incurred now By YOU. A hand takes the record from him. Maria places a folded piece of paper into the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I wish to convey a special message from my heart. Andreyev and Pervak both disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: I wish to convey this record to Comrade STALIN.  4l 42 43 44 20 May 2016 Draft 10 19. Pervak and Maria wrestling for the record.

dialogues.text: Vasily, your father is dead and... Vasily draws his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Dividing the spoils? Leave his brain alone! How old are you? Beria nods at the NKVD. An NKVD man tries to grab Vasily' gun but he fires it.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 54. Everyone dives for cover. Malenkov runs out of the door a pulls it shut. Bulganin and Khrushchev try to follow but Malenkov's holding it shut from the other side. Khrushche crouches against the door. Mikoyan stands fearless. NKVD men try to subdue Vasily. He struggles, firing his g

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here is your fucking... harvest! They drag him away from Stalin but he fires more shots. T hit Stalin. His head rocks forward as if the shots have jolted him into life for a moment. The NKVD get his gun off him. We hear Svetlana's voice.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vasily! Vasily! Stop!... She's come into the garage. Her voice stops him strugglin

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Tiny child doctors are cutting up Papasha! They're filling his brain with American lies! She grabs his face, looks right into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (very quiet) He’s gone, Vasya. Just you and me now. Be careful. Remember what Papa said. Wade gently across the river because... (chythmically digging into his face) It. Is. Full. Of. Snakes. And. Crocodiles. Vasily nods. He's heard her. Svetlana looks at the NKVD m

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: (trying to act normal) Someone could have told me what to expect. Next time, tell me. Beria nods to the NKVD, who let him go. Malenkov opens the door and comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) I understand wanting to leave. But why hold the door shut? Who does that?

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Cover me, I’m getting Papa!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 55. Suddenly, Vasily grabs for his gun. Malenkov immediately closes himself outside again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Off you go, kitten! The NKVD men struggle with Vasily, force him to the groun and sit on him. It's not dignified. Svetlana looks ashame

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (close to Vasily) Moron. I’m not part of your suicide pact. You want to die? Shoot yourself.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: You will regret this! You are sitting on fire! Fire!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: He's distressed. We all are. (to doctors) Is it done? One of the petrified doctors nods.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is finished. Let's go. And someone do something about all of this - (waves vaguely at Stalin) - then take it to the Kremlin.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Where now for me? And my brother?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: My men will bring you to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I would be honoured to escort you. Svetlana senses Beria’s antipathy to Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Thank you. But no, I’1l go with Beria’s men. Beria kisses her and marches out into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Our precious cargo. (shouting) Khrustalyov! My car! The other committee members look at each other for a beat then rush off after him. Suddenly everyone's in a hurry.  93 94 95 20 May 2016 Draft 10 56.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: We need equilibrium. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: “Equilibrium”, bollocks. Give me chaos every time. Got more meat on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria arrives at his limo. Khrustalyov opens the door and gets in. An NKVD officer is in the driver seat, Khrustaly stays outside. He nods to his boss and heads into the dac Inside the car, the young waitress Beria saw earlier is cuffed to the car door. She's frightened. He smiles at he

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I know. Sad times. The car starts but the courtyard’s a logjam of vehicles a trying to get out. Other committee members hurry to their vehicles, drivers holding open the doors for them. Svetla heads with an NKVD man to her limo. Horns start to blare. Political manoeuvering. NKVD men trying futilely to direc Then, in the chaos, NKVD men emerge carrying a plain wood coffin. They load it onto the back of a truck and climb i Beria gets out of his car. Stands solemnly. The others ar obliged to get out and show their respect. The NKVD clear path for the truck and escorts. Beria’s car following. He won the scramble. The others start their cars. Horns blaring, cars jostling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the limos drive away. An empty road. Silence. Then - a rumbling, getting nearer. A CONVOY of NKVD truck coming up the road, through the gates, into the courtyard Armed NKVD MEN pour out, occupying the house and grounds. Kobulov barks into a loudhailer.

dialogues.speaker: KOBULOV
dialogues.text: Comrades! We share your grief! You will assemble in the courtyard for further instructions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busts, portraits, furniture, files, are removed, and medi equipment from the outhouse. Stalin's turntable, the reco still on it, is loaded into a box, nailed shut.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 57. Some STAFF are already in a line in front of the house, others are brought out by the NKVD, including the chef an the doctors. Some have belongings, some nothing. A lot of orders are being shouted. People are frightened, confused A supposedly dead Stalin, in a dressing gown and slippers marched out. The chef turns to his confused neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: His lookalike. I think his contract just ran out. The LOOKALIKE is taken round the corner to be shot. But t SOLDIER executioner can’t do it. Looks like HIM. Someone quickly throws a cloth over the lookalike’s head. Good. B A second lookalike is marched out. Another, third lookali clearly a younger, fitter man, makes a break for it. Clos of a young, fit Stalin running for his life away from the dacha. But we cut away before any mine explosion. In fact the explosion doesn't come...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. STALIN'S DACHA
dialogues.text: Delov and Two NKVD OFFICERS search the kitchen. They disc Matryona, crouched between two gas stoves, her eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: DELOV
dialogues.text: Hey, you! On your feet! Matryona is hauled up and dragged out the front door. Now we hear and just about see a mine explode in the wood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier and sergeant are asleep. Khrustalyov appears Pervak.

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: Attention! The soldiers dozily comes to attention.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSTALYOV
dialogues.text: At ease. You can stand down now. There's food in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. They head down a long corridor with a kitchen at the end. Then the sergeant comes back into view, collapsing to the floor, unconscious. NKVD arms reach into the doorway fram our view and drag him out.  98 99 20 May 2016 Draft 10 58. The other soldier runs across the doorway followed by two NKVD MEN. It's messy. The soldier may have gotten away in the woods. We don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loaded trucks pull out of the courtyard. We are with Matryona as the truck moves off. From her pov see Khrustalyov join Kobulov in the courtyard. They get smaller and smaller in the distance. Kobulov shoots Khrustalyov in the head. Other landmines go off.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Khrushchev is chopping vegetables. A tired Bulganin is sa the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: So... Beria's introduced 'special measures' to 'reduce the panic'? Carrots. He looks at Bulganin, meaningfully, as if sounding him ou Bulganin passes him a couple of carrots.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's good to prepare, get everything ready. He looks at Bulganin, meaningfully, as if sounding him ou

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Are we talking about Beria or the stroganoff? Khrushchev goes over to his washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I built a big factory making these. Khrushchev turns it on. It makes a terrifyingly loud nois

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: (shouting over it) If Russia was a noise, then that would be it.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Not so good for washing clothes. Very useful for “conversations”..about Beria.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 59. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Look, it's important someone takes control.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Someone like Beria? The conversation is suddenly significant. Bulganin comes to Khrushchev so they can talk quietly.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: It should certainly be someone who has the support of all parts of the party.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Like Beria?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Well certainly one of us.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: So... maybe not Beria?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: You're very good with that knife. It’s ...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I'm saying... maybe not be Beria... We should get rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes! And soon! Punish him! Stick him in a room with twelve big hungry, horny Serbians! Suddenly the washing machine comes to a juddery stop, interrupting Bulganin. The men stare at one another in pa Khrushchev tastes a spoonful of food, not yet ready to ea

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Mmm. That is good. Delicious. The machine starts again. Khrushchev spits out the food.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feh! Raw!

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: We should take acting classes. If Stalin hadn't killed all the actors. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 May 2016 Draft 10 60.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I want to come on board, but we don't have the numbers. Suddenly the phone rings. Has someone been listening in? Tentatively Bulganin answers as Khrushchev adds some of t vegetables to a pot on the stove. We see Malenkov, Mikoyan standing next to him, by the win of his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Are you being factional?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: We're cooking some food. Khrushchev grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I can see you, you know. We cut to reveal the two apartment windows look on to eac other, very close in distance. We see Khrushchev in one window, Malenkov in the other. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Looks like factionalism to me. Khrushchev grabs a spoonful of stew and stands at the win theatrically eating it.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Tastes like lamb stroganoff to me. Khrushchev hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm acting secretary general and I'm - oh, he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, squeal any higher and you'll burst your hymen.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: They're being factional

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: So are we.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I’m Acting General Secretary. How can I be plotting against myself? Khrushchev closes the blinds.  100 101 20 May 2016 Draft 10 61.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: On the committee it’s you, me, Kaganovich. Three against three. But there’s also Molotov.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: But he’s on the... (mimes “headshot” ) ...list.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We tell him - Beria put him there. Beria killed his wife. Molotov’s revenge gets us FOUR. Khrushchev goes through to another room, and peers outsid through a window. His POV: in a different block to Malenkov's, Molotov stares out of his window, grief-stric

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (epiphany ) He’s at home. I’d better get over there before Beria and his sausage- faced clowns do.... The washing machine stops again.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (furious, to the machine) You piece of metal shit! (to Bulganin) Look after the food... He rushes off, full of urgency.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: What do I do? Add salt, right? That's what people who can cook do. We hear Khrushchev shouting back as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Recipe book's under the sink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev hurries down the stairs, out across the courty to Molotov's stairwell opposite. The elevator’s at the se floor and rising. He's out of breath but he’s on a missio He takes the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoner POV of Beria's face. He's close again. Too close He's quietly singing a traditional Russian folk song.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 62.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: "In a field a birch tree stood..." No? Come, your voice was once so beautiful, Paulina Molitova. He clicks his fingers, “remembers”.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Meant to say. Stalin's dead! We open up to reveal a woman - POLINA - in her late 50s, in a tiny, barren cell. She looks haggard, wrecked.

dialogues.speaker: POLINA
dialogues.text: (shocked) No! Our Stalin?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Yes, “your” Stalin. The one who put you here. The waitress and an NKVD GUARD are also in the cell. Beria hauls Polina up. She doesn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come! Let's smarten you up. (to waitress) Sorry, darling. Work. I’1l make it up to you. (to guard) Fetch the mattress and have her washed. He walks Polina out while Ilyin and another NKVD Man brin flowers, a rug and a jug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria leads Polina down a corridor. An NKVD GUARD comes the other way, with Slimonov, handcuf

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: S...s...limonov, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SLIMONOV
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: F..f..f£..farewell, Slimonov! Slimonov is led away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev wheezes up three flights, pausing for breath before disappearing onto Molotov's landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev, exhausted and sweaty, reaches Molotov's door knocks. He tries to compose himself but looks quite ill. Molotov opens the door. He's been crying. Khrushchev barr through, pulling Molotov with him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Christ, you look like you’re about to be bulldozed into a lime pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few moments later. Khrushchev is over the toilet bowl. Molotov is stood behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Do you want me to hold back your hair? Polina always used to do that for me.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I... wanted to invite you to tomorrow's committee meeting...

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (snaps back) Why wouldn't I be at the meeting? Khrushchev flushes.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Beria and Stalin put you on a list.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (shocked, hurt) Stalin? I must have wronged him so badly...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Are you cracked? Beria wanted you out. But listen. We can honour his legacy by making sure Beria doesn’t...

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Oh! No, no, no. This sounds like factionalism, Nicky. Stalin didn’t like...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 64.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (loses it) Stalin's dead. It's over. We have to act.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (crying) I can’t believe he’s gone... Khrushchev tries to flush the toilet again. The cistern hasn't filled up yet. He tries a couple more times. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) It takes a while to... Khrushchev gives up, keeps his voice down instead.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Come on. That fucking slug Beria had your wife killed. He can’t be trusted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molotov and Khrushchev walk back towards the living room.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: She betrayed Stalin and she betrayed me.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Housekeeping!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molotov and Khrushchev come through into the living room find Beria. Everyone's surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA/KHRUSHCHEV/MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (at the same time) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We were just chatting about Polina.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Well, would you believe it?..

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: The treacherous bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: .«..Or: a wronged woman who was framed.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 65.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Come on, Stalin found her guilty! She collaborated with the zionists. Polina's at the doorway. Only Beria can see her. This is going to plan.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: She was a criminal. I’m glad she’s dead... Molotov notices her in the doorway. They look at each oth The barriers drop - it's clear he still loves her.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (hasn't seen her yet) She plotted to poison Stalin... He sees Molotov heading towards Polina. He can't believe

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Is it really you?

dialogues.speaker: POLINA
dialogues.text: (full of love) I'm back, Vyacheslav. They hug, emotional. Beria enjoys it. Khrushchev tries to himself out of his hole.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: But the evidence was flimsy. No witnesses, no corroboration... No... Khrushchev gives up. Beria puts his arm round Molotov and Polina. It becomes a group hug.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Molotov) I kept her safe. For you, Vyacheslav. (to Polina) And I kept HIM safe. For you, Polina. Beria throws a victorious glance at Khrushchev. Molotov breaks down, overwhelmed. Khrushchev tentatively joins the group hug.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Well done. Well done, everyone.

dialogues.speaker: OP.37
dialogues.text: The young waitress from the dacha hunches on the bed of t spruced up cell. The door opens. Beria is there with flow

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Hello, my sweet. He moves to the table, where a bottle of wine has been uncorked. He sniffs it lasciviously, eyeing her legs.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mm. Everything at room temperature. Oh, lighten up. It could be worse. Be warned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A miserable Khrushchev eats the stroganoff, occasionally looking out across the courtyard at the Molotovs, arm in Nina has a mouthful. Grim. Khrushchev sees her disgust, silently picks up both plates, scrapes them into a bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress' frightened PARENTS wait. She appears - distraught, stoical. An NKVD GUARD hands the parents Beri bouquet. They hurry off.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVE MATERIAL 2. 111
dialogues.text: RUSSIA IN MOURNING. A red flag with black border flies ab the walls of the Kremlin. Beyond it: Moscow, with more re and-black flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our footage: NKVD ARRIVING IN VEHICLES, TAKING UP POSTS/MAKING ROADBLOCKS ON MOSCOW STREETS. MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Zis limousine arrives at the Kremlin.  114 20 May 2016 Draft 10 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria walks jauntily through connecting doorways from the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malenkov being made up to look like a leader. He’s uncomfortable under studio lights as the PHOTOGRAPHER sna away and STAFFERS bustle in and out with business. Two MA UP ARTISTS blotting and repairing his make-up.

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: Comrade, I’ve scheduled telephone calls later with...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Then tell me LATER. Beria arrives, looks at Malenkov and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Almost perfect. Perhaps... an apple just here, in the mouth? Chuckling, Malenkov wipes his face with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you. (over shoulder) I’1ll be back shortly! A smiling Malenkov grabs Beria and walks stiffly with him into the middle room. He drops the smile to show his fury MALENKOV (CONT’D) Don’t you ever, EVER, do that again. Humiliate me in front of...I’m the General Secretary!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (deferential) I'm mortified. Genuinely.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Looking my best for the People is a duty. Malenkov walks through the middle room and into the third room. His walks still seems a little stiff.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Of course. Shall we...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (spotting Pervak) What now?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 68.

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: Apologies. The seating plan for...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Give it to Blavatsky. He’s an expert at sitting on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Shall we get onto..

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yes, the committee meeting. Item One. The lists. These arrests and “interrogations”. Do we just take them down a gear, or....

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Hold off altogether?

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What, “freeze” them?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: “Freeze”? Excellent thought. Yes, we could freeze arrests, maybe even release some low-level prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck me. Really? Is this what the old man would have wanted?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Stalin was radical and popular.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Liberalisation WOULD be radical. Now Delov has edged a little way into the room. MALENKOV (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: No, this is something I wanted to show you. Beria walks stiffly to the third room. Malenkov follows, if he was going to do anyway. Delov produces on a stand an iconic photograph of Stalin hugging a young girl on a balcony.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought, a photo of you and the girl. Continuity?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 69.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (delighted) Good idea. We show how we’re taking Stalin’s humanity forward...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Delov) Find this girl. They leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Malenkov and Beria walking to the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: My chief concern is admitting we were wrong. All those arrests. And deaths...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: We were being loyal. I promoted Stalin’s truth without question. I can promote a new truth without blinking. An unblinking beat.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, I’1l push on with the releases?

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Alright, but proceed carefully.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Fuck this up and I’1l have you shot. Beria says nothing. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Just joking. I was testing you.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Is that a corset? ANGLE on Malenkov’s body. A GIRDLE is apparent.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: It's a girdle. Different thing altogether.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You wear it well.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 70.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: But not worth raising with the Committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several more Zis limousines arrive at the Kremlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee sit at a table in an impressive, high-ceili room. Malenkov is at the head of the table with his new hairdo and a smart new outfit. The room is dominated by a giant portrait of Stalin.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: So, in accordance with... (re portrait) .--his will, I propose Comrade Malenkov be named Chairman of the Council of Ministers. And General Secretary of the Party.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (pompous nod) And I propose Comrade Beria for First Vice-Chairman, Council of Ministers. Those in favour. Beria, Malenkov and Mikoyan instantly put their hands up.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Wait. Those are two separate proposals. Comrade Beria is incredibly busy combining his roles as Minister for both the Interior and Security. It would perhaps be kinder for someone else to carry the happy burden of Vice-Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I thank Comrade Khrushchev for his concern but I can assure you that I'm capable of doing two things at once.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Well, it would actually be three things.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Let's move to a vote. (to Beria) On both proposals? Beria gesticulates as if to say 'Up to you'.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 71. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Yes, on both. Me as General Secretary and Comrade Beria as Vice- Chairman. All those in favour? Malenkov, Beria and Mikoyan raise their hands. Molotov jo them, then Bulganin and Kaganovich. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Carried... Grudgingly, Khrushchev raises his hand. MALENKOV (CONT’D) ..+-unanimously. Next...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We need someone to take charge of the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: What about Comrade Khrushchev?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (looking at Beria) Where’s this come from?

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yes, good thought.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I formally propose that Comrade Khrushchev be given the honour of organising the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Beria) But that will tie up all of my time, won't it?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: If I can do three jobs at once, you can at least do two.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: But I need to be...

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You wanted to honour his legacy. You told me last night, in the bathroom. Molotov winks at Khrushchev: he's doing him a great favou

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV/BERIA
dialogues.text: All those in favour..  20 May 2016 Draft 10 72. Again, Molotov, Beria, Malenkov and Mikoyan raise their hands. Kaganovich decides to raise his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: (justifying himself) You'd be good at it. Bulganin raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Carried... U... una... Then, grudgingly again, Khrushchev. MALENKOV (CONT’D) .-carried unanimously.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Thank you. I shall remember this. Beria looks to Malenkov.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (trying to be formal) Comrade Beria. Beria clears his throat, looks extravagantly at ease.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I propose a halt to deportations. The release of some existing detainees. And the suspension of arrests officially sanctioned three days ago... Molotov, Khrushchev, Kaganovich and Bulganin are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: You dare wipe your shitting arse on Stalin's lists!?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Let's all stay calm... although what you just said is utterly ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (angry) One of you look me in the eye and tell me you’re not heartsick at the relentless, pointless arrests. Death after death after DEATH. A charged beat as he looks around the room, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I believe we must embrace a new reality.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 73. MALENKOV (CONT’D) (“wanker” mime) Yeah. “Embrace” it...

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: How are we going to explain all the people you very comprehensively arrested in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: If there were errors, if people misguided us then we punish those who did the misguiding...

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Arrest anyone who carried out a wrongful arrest? Lavrentiy, come on. We ALL signed off on that shit...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (thinks he can be commanding) Stalin destroyed the status quo and built a new one. He was radical.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: This is deliberately being rushed through. We don’t have time to..

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I thought you were in favour of a more liberal approach, Comrade Reformer. Khrushchev remains silent, roiling with conflicting emoti

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: We must step back...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: All those in favour...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (interrupting) ...of pausing the arrests and executions and so on? Malenkov and Beria raise their arms. Mikoyan, reluctantly joins them. Bulganin, Khrushchev and Kaganovich look at Molotov.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: I have always been loyal to Stalin. Always. And these arrests were authorised by Stalin.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 74. The rest of the committee follow Molotov’s lengthy logic increasing frustration. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) But Stalin was always loyal to the collective leadership. That is true loyalty. But he had an iron principle, undeviating, strong. Shouldn’t we do the same, and stick to what we believed in? No. It’s stronger still to forge one’s own beliefs into the beliefs of collective leadership. (a beat) Which I have now done. Molotov raises his hand. Kaganovich and Bulganin raise theirs. Finally, Khrushchev raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Carried...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Good, I'll oversee...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Unanimously.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I'll oversee the releases. We have unloosened the Union’s great corset. Nikita, you've some swatches and bouquets to look at. A funeral doesn't organise itself. We stay on Khrushchev as Molotov leans over. Malenkov prattles on in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (To Khrushchev) You've won! Do him proud.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (in background) Beria, I want you to put together a communique for the press. I'll supervise the transfer of the body. Comrade Bulganin, tell the army; Comrade Mikoyan, the factories and the unions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty prisoners, including the shot by 5 GUARDS and CHASOV. 119 Nervous Man, lined up to be  120 20 May 2016 Draft 10 75.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: Long live Stalin!

dialogues.speaker: CHASOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Stalin's dead. Comrade Malenkov's in charge now.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: Long live Mal... Chasov shoots him just as an NKVD officer, SHULGA runs up

dialogues.speaker: SHULGA
dialogues.text: Stop shooting! Chasov turns, but fires off one more shot. It kills the Nervous Man, who slumps dead in the background.

dialogues.speaker: SHULGA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating list) Amnesties effective immediately. Orders of Comrade Beria. We're pulling out. They hurry off to join their colleagues. The NKVD’s mobilising, heading off. The prisoners are left, confused

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up of Stalin’s face in his coffin. Pull out and hig reveal enormous hall with people bustling, making last-mi preparations. The UNDERTAKERS’ finishing touches: doing make-up, hair, moustache, polishing buttons. Huge flags hang from the ceiling. More are being rigged. Swathes of red, and flowe everywhere. Beria and Malenkov stroll along the other side of the hal

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Interrogations are on hold. First time we've had a chance to bleach the cells. Also, I’ve signed off a few amnesties. Petty thieves, harmless idiots... MEZHNIKOV (mid 50s, fussy), the designer responsible for funeral, stands beside a frustrated Khrushchev (in a red armband with black borders) at the head of Stalin's coffi

dialogues.speaker: MEZHNIKOV
dialogues.text: Now, curtains. Ruched or not ruched?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 76.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Ruched? What the fuck is ruched? Mezhnikov demonstrates with the material under the coffin

dialogues.speaker: MEZHNIKOV
dialogues.text: Ruched. Not ruched. Ruched. Not ruched.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Why should I care? While you were hiding in your mama’s linen closet I was at Stalingrad! I ate rats. Raw rats. Didn't even cook them! Behind him, a nervous group of STEELWORKERS. Awkward, overawed. Khrushchev in his element with the Steelworkers

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, the Steelworkers. Some REAL men! Lads, come, come! Malenkov moves over to assert his authority. Beria spots line of girls and moves over to them.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Iron and steel are the very foundation of...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Steelworkers) Iron? IRON? Derisory laughter.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Capitalism was built on iron. STEEL - is the 20th Century. The Soviet Union is made of steel! And these! Men! Made it! Huge wave of suppressed applause, caught between joyous approval of Khrushchev and the solemnity of the place. Delov arrives with a group of sweet, very Russian-looking girls, aged 7-9.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: You found my girl?

dialogues.speaker: DELOV
dialogues.text: We can't find her, Comrade Minis... Comrade General Secretary. These are suggested alternatives.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (to Khrushchev) Find her!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 77.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I thought you bastards knew where EVERYONE was! Find her, camel-cock! Pervak is stood awkwardly behind him with Maria Yudina, t pianist. Khrushchev turns and switches into chivalrous mo

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maria Veniaminovna. Please. Forgive my language, but he IS... one of those. This... He gestures towards Malenkov who holds out his hand but s seen Stalin in his coffin. It hits her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Stalin!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Yes. Stalin. Malenkov is left hanging. He joins in the solemn moment.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Sad times. Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I can’t TELL you... the intensity of emotion when I heard. General ZHUKHOV - 57, imposing, covered in medals - strid to the coffin, booming greetings to officers in the hall. He's followed by some of his ENTOURAGE.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: If it wasn’t for this man, I wouldn’t be here today. - He lent me his driver! Hah! (to Pervak) Pervak! Handsome as ever! Put you in a frock, I'd marry you myself!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (returning) Ah, the generalissimo.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: So, what does a war hero have to do to get some lubrication round here? (grabs one out of Delov's hand) Christ! Where’s this from, a Polish flamethrower? Tastes like PISS... Slow-mo on Zhukhov as he drawls out 'Piss' with the capti  20 May 2016 Draft 10 78. “FIELD MARSHAL ZHUKHOV, HEAD OF THE SOVIET ARMY".

dialogues.speaker: SPEED
dialogues.text: As the others talk, Mezhnikov shows Malenkov a choice of portraits of him on boards to pick from. Zhukhov reaches the others. He kisses

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nikita! Sorry to hear about your wife's affair! (off his reaction) She hasn’t had one yet but God, I like the look of her. Hah!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Yes, she is... pretty.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Zhukhov. So rare to see you away from a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Beria. Must be such a... (re coffin) ..-difficult time for you, hiding your happiness at a promotion. (to Khrushchev) Who stood down the army? Why have my men been sent back to their barracks? I’m smiling but I’m very fucking furious.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (notices Maria) Perhaps Comrade Yudina should prepare those precious hands.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Maria, I am mortified I cannot escort you, but... her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: How very friendly. You never kiss my hand anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: So lovely to see you again, Comrade Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Again?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 79.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I taught his wife’s niece to play.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Katya! Yes, we were both at the salon recital...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I LOVE the idea of you at a “salon”. You have a party trick? Burping the alphabet? She sets off, passing Beria who whispers at her.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So many... (mimes piano-playing) ..-notes. Like your one to Stalin. Which I have. She looks back as she walks away, rattled.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: So who confined the army to barracks?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: That nonsense was NOT signed off by the whole committee.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Ah, so it was only one idiot, not the full set. Malenkov has chosen the portrait he likes. He joins them.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Talk of the devil.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Zhukhov) The decision was mine supported by Comrade Malenkov...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (not sure what they’re discussing) We took a view. And made a decision...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: We're discussing the city security.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I know.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 80.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (about Malenkov’s hair) Christ, did Coco Chanel shit on your head? (to Beria) Moscow will be boiling with people. Your pansy torturers won't cope, you know. That’s a job for MEN.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I have PLENTY. NKVD AND the...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Interior troops. Merged now, into this “KGB”...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (kissy lips) “KGB”. Even SOUNDS like a bunch of nancies.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: We're controlling the crowd at source. All trains inbound to Moscow have been cancelled...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (interrupts) But... I'm the trains! I'm the fucking funeral, I... I should have been asked.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (to Khrushchev) Please, Sir. I need to go...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I think she needs the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) You need the army here. Not Beria’s Keystone Cops.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Maybe we should see who can mobilise first. Oh. It seems to be me... He heads off before Zhukhov can answer.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (to Zhukhov) We've got this under control. (to Khrushchev) You: find me the right girl. (to little girl) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you: go to that lady over there and she'll take you to the toilet. He sets off after Beria. Delov heads off with the girls.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: I need to punch someone.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: May I suggest... Khrushchev nods at a stack of boards with a portrait of a very airbrushed Malenkov being carried past.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: He looks like my auntie after two peach brandies.

dialogues.speaker: MEZHNIKOV
dialogues.text: (calls from by the doors) We're opening the doors! A line of MEN IN COLOURFUL AIR FORCE/NAVY UNIFORMS take position at intervals from the door to the coffin and bey We hear a large CROWD coming up the stairs. They pour in through the doors, a tidal wave of grieving humanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our footage of queues outside the Hall of Columns.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVE MATERIAL 3. 122
dialogues.text: Footage of crowds gathering all over Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Kiev footage of people leaving their houses, traipsin down Moscow streets. We focus on a FAMILY; a mother, fath and their two young children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor people, many in tears, walk along tracks, towards a barrier. NKVD MEN with machine guns stand by. Their senio officer is FEDIN.  125 126 127 128 20 May 2016 Draft 10 82.

dialogues.speaker: FEDIN
dialogues.text: No trains to Moscow! No... go... go back to your homes... The crowd of people turn around and trudge purposefully a the railway track. Among them is the family we saw in scl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our shots of crowds growing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our footage of the queue filing past Stalin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Svetlana chatting to Bulganin and Mikoyan, who clearly ha to be somewhere else but feel obliged to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: ..-Papa always spoke with great fondness of you two. “My hammer and sickle” he always used to say, although I was never sure which...

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Never heard that before. How...gratifying.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: I'd be the sickle. Sharp. Poor Comrade Bulganin here...well, see he even has a head like the blunt end of a ball hammer...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (off polite laughter) My father always used to say go to you two when I need advice.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: ..or help...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 83.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (a hand on each) “They are true and loyal men.”

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Any time. Any time at all. Sorry, we have to take our places. Svetlana alone. She leans over a balustrade, watching the grieving crowd. Beria joins her.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: This is... real. Nobody’s making them do this. In the crowd below: grandmothers sob; a sailor removes hi hat out of respect but drops it. The crowd keep moving an scrabbles his way back to try and get his hat.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you want a chair? Beria signals to an NKVD man who approaches with a chair.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I haven't sat down since he died. He was too big. You have to stand.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (what? ) Yes. Beria signals “no”. The NKVD man leaves with the chair.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Do you remember Yuri?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (no) I remember everyone. It’s a gift.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I loved him.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (suddenly remembers) Yuri Zhednov! Yes, special to you, I know. Some unsuitable associates. Tragic, really. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I want you to bring him back.  129 130 131 20 May 2016 Draft 10 84.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (are you mad?) But, my chick, how?

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: You brought Molotov’s wife back.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: She was... I'd kept her.....

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: You're returning so many people to their homes. I want ONE person. Is that really too much? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: For you, I will attempt the impossible. He opens his arms to her. She awkwardly steps into them.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I hate seeing you sad.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (awkward) I hate that you hate seeing me sad. They hug awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd files past the coffin: ordinary citizens mingle with representatives from nations and regions carrying demarcated floral tributes. Andreyev and Sergei supervise music from a balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR FOOTAGE of the committee: Molotov, Kaganovich, Bulgan Khrushchev, Malenkov, Beria and, closest to the public, Mikoyan, who's crying. A large wreath nearly brushes his face. He sneezes. A film crew is recording.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 85.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: (sotto) Fucking pollen. They should make gas bombs with this stuff. Molotov, sobbing heavily, looks across, sees him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: I know. I know... The wreaths and bouquets are getting absurdly big. One - the message "From the grieving people of Uzbekistan" on i only just fits through the large double doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) I think that's actually larger than the region itself. Malenkov’s little involuntary laugh. Molotov sees, disapproves.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (chiding Beria) Inappropriate. The Uzbek bouquet makes its way past. On the staircase, s mitres bobbing up and down, some very worn. A group of ORTHODOX BISHOPS approaching in full regalia. Shocked whispers from committee members. Not Beria. MALENKOV (CONT’D) No!

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! It's the bishops!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: What are these bastards doing at MY

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Did I dream the last 36 years? Are we doing the revolution again from the START?

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: The Church belongs where we left it. In a ditch.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Tell Mikoyan to sneeze on the bastards as they go past.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Did you invite them?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 86.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Ask Beria if it was him.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Don’t order me around. (to Bulganin) Ask Beria if he invited the fucking bishops.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: (to Beria) Did you invite the fucking bishops?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Yes. Bulganin turns back, chewing over Beria’s answer.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Well? Bulganin nods to Malenkov.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yes. He did.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I'm going to give everyone in Red Square a voucher permitting one kick each to his stupid face.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Bulganin) Is he asking for more delicious hay?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: No. He said something quite complicated about a voucher system.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: This is rehabili... Listen to me! This is rehabilitation of the most counter revolutionary elements! He can't do that without the committee.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (taking over from Bulganin) He says you can't do it without the committee. Which is true...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 87.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I can cancel house arrests under article 31. Malenkov realises he is right.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (to Khrushchev) He can in fact cancel house arrests under article 31. The camera crew is on them again. They all look as solemn they can. The bishops pass the coffin, making the sign of cross.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Tell him that I... Actually, swap... Swap...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Swap!

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We can make it look like it's part of the ceremony. A dignified Khrushchev steps forward. Malenkov motionless staring at NAVY OFFICERS struggling to get a too-high wre through the door. The officers back up, then advance solemnly in a squattin position. The wreath low enough to go through but still t wide. Khrushchev eases back into line.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (whispers to Khrushchev) If only someone had checked... The navy officers back up again with the wreath, then wal with it sideways and squatting. Suddenly, an angry voice, away from the crowd. Vasily, in full uniform, drunk, trying to get to the coffin. Arguing with SENIOR NKVD OFFICERS, one of whom has a loudhailer.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: They're murderers! Murderers! Give me your loudhailer!...  132 20 May 2016 Draft 10 88. From their balcony, Andreyev and Sergei see Vasily. Serge turns up a dial and the music grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (whispers to Khrushchev) Did you forget to give him his sedatives?

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: .»-If you don't hand it over I'll shove it so far up your arse your farts will deafen Moscow! (to Committee) .»--I KNOW YOU KILLED MY FATHER!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (whispers to Bulganin) Tell them to get the steel workers. (to Malenkov) We have to go!... The whisper goes from Bulganin to Kaganovich to Molotov t Tarasov, who hurries off. Vasily, now restrained, getting louder.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTONED-UP SACKS OF SHIT
dialogues.text: Some of the crowd are starting to notice. Sergei raises t volume a bit more.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREYEV
dialogues.text: Don't record this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of STEEL WORKERS chat and smoke, putting on new overalls and caps bearing the hammer and sickle. Some hav medals. Tarasov runs in.

dialogues.speaker: TARASOV
dialogues.text: Quick! We need you now! NOW! The steel workers are confused - they're not ready. TARASOV (CONT’D) Are you actually made of steel? Now! Move! The NKVD bundle them outside as, frenzied, they put out cigarettes, haul on jackets and, in one case, trousers.  133 134 20 May 2016 Draft 10 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steel workers emerge in a rush, trying to look dignif Some are still hopping along, getting dressed. Vasily struggling with officers. One has his hand over Vasily's mouth. A bite - ouch - he lets go. Beria, over his shoulder, sees the steel workers approach

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Move, you hairy-assed sluggards! They all turn to go. The manoeuvre turns into hesitant ch Molotov’s in front.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Liars and revisionists! You killed Stalin! Molotov sets off and the others follow him. He's not sett a fast enough pace - those at the back bunch up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Decorum, please..

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Faster, you SNAIL.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (to Vasily, trying to be both quiet and loud)

dialogues.speaker: SHHHHHH
dialogues.text: Pursued by the NKVD, Vasily rushes up some stairs. Beria breaks from the line, speed-walks until he's pretty much out of public view then breaks into a run and heads the staircase. Khrushchev follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet holding area. Some Communist LEADERS including ZH ENLAI, with their TRANSLATORS. Vasily rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Friends! There has been a terrible crime! Zhou EnLai's translator translates for the Chinese leader

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father - they killed him. They got a child to cut out his brain and send it to Washington!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 90. Zhou Enlai's TRANSLATOR stops, then carries on.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re ruthless monsters and sodomites! The translator is trying to get every nuance. An NKVD officer grabs Vasily and pull him away.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-+.sucking the cocks and balls of New York Zionist queers in petticoats... The translator makes sure he does the insult justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NKVD wrestle Vasily to the ground. Beria and Khrushch arrive.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: I‘1l make sure you all stand trial and get garotted by your own lookalikes in Red Square...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Vasily. It's me. Beria kneels beside Vasily who tries to spit at him, but lying down, so the spit just drops back onto his face.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Syphilitic cannibals! Zoo animals..

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: I know about the dead hockey team. The pretence. The denial. Vasily stops struggling. He's accepted defeat.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Freak weather. (calmly) I want to make a speech at the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (To Khrushchev) He wants to make a speech at the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
