dialogues.text: Oh, MORE good news.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 gl. The Dignitaries from inside the room quietly file out, an past Vasily and Co. VASILY. I'm his son. (flaring up again, struggling) Let me speak, you howling chimps... Zhukhov appears, pushes Vasily into the now-vacated dignitaries room and punches Vasily hard across the face, knocking out a tooth. Vasily falls to the floor, unconsci Zhukhov pockets the tooth.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: I'll stick it under my pillow tonight. May even make a ruble. He smiles at Beria - that's how you sort things round her Beria notices that Svetlana's watching a few yards away, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Lana! He's my godson. I won't let anything happen to him. She turns and hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Something has already happened to him!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Lana! (to an NKVD man) Tell her I'll be with her ina moment. The NKVD man sets off after Svetlana.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (grabs Beria, and makes sure no-one else is around in the room) Not yet! (close, angry) You're bringing the Church back? What next? Are the Romanovs coming?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Don’t be hysterical. We are ina new reality.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 92.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well don’t you sound fancy? You locked half the nation up. Beat them. Raped them. Killed them.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Yes, and now I'm releasing them. I put so many in jail, there are so many to let go. You won’t believe how many will be free. Millions! The revolutions continues...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Not true. You're just doing it to gain power. You bend and crack the truth, like it was a human body.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Oh, you want the “truth”? Let’s start with you calling the blameless Polina Molotova a Zionist spy. In her own apartment. I heard you. And so did my men. He taps his ear to indicate they were listening.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: But she was found guilty. You FOUND her guilty.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Past tense. In those “old days” you pine for, Nicky, that dissonance would get you shot. Khrushchev starts to speak, Beria cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More truth: you called that slut doctor Timashuk to Stalin's bedside...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: That was your idea!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You initiated it. Again, there are recordings. A woman who denounced thousands of innocent doctors. Khrushchev is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We ALL signed off on those arrests.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You're old regime, Khrushchev. Counter-revolutionary. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The man who fucked up the flowers and invited his bit-on-the-side whore to play at the funeral. Even though she swore to kill Stalin. Who’s now dead.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Beria hands him Maria's note.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: She wanted Stalin dead and she knows your family. It's lucky we now live in the new Soviet Union or you and your wife and children would now be a pile of dust on the floor of a crematorium toilet. Khrushchev reads the note. The colour drains from his fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev comes back down the stairs and into the Hall o Columns. He sees some bishops in the distance, calls to an NKVD gu

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Get those boyfriends of Christ out of my sight! We see the Bishops being moved away. There is some applau coming from a section of the queue.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see they agree with me.

dialogues.speaker: NKVD GUARD
dialogues.text: No, Comrade Khrushchev, it’s because they’ve spotted him. He gestures over to the applauding section of the crowd. can just make out Beria walking past, enjoying the applau

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Start the trains. The people can come to Moscow! Meanwhile Beria is enjoying his moment. He’s with Kubulov

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: The revolution continues! (to Kubulov) Now start the other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black maria pulls up. Several confused PRISONERS, some beaten, some of whom we saw arrested earlier, get out. Th van drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The provincial train TRACKS we saw earlier. Crowds are ca in front of the NKVD and Fedin with pictures of Stalin, candles, flowers etc. A whistle blows.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN GUARD
dialogues.text: For Moscow! Train to Moscow! People rush forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distinctive design we saw earlier. The woman turns aw from the window. She's heard something. The middle-aged m who was arrested has returned. He's been beaten. She rushes over and hugs him. His son sits awkwardly in a chair: it's the young man who betrayed him to the NKVD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROWDS clamber onto the train, including the FAMILY WITH CHILDREN we saw earlier. Excitement, people clambering on board. Train packed full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRISONER and the NKVD Interrogator from sc 73. The cell door opens and a SOLDIER points a gun. The Interrogator m to allow a clearer shot at the Prisoner. But the Soldier shoots the Interrogator. The Prisoner’s relieved moan. Th Soldier shoots him too, and leaves. We hear O.S a success of unlocking doors, yells and double-gunshots  142 143 20 May 2016 Draft 10 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KHRUSHCHEV alone, slowly making his way up the stairs. He hear piano music. Someone practicing. He is trying to fin the source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room full of images of Stalin, and some of Malenk

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (holding out note) This your work, is it? Cut to Maria sitting as if in an interrogation, but with piano nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Why? Are there spelling mistakes?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (suddenly furious) Don’t ever speak to me like that again or I'll break your fingers! (waving note) The ammunition you've given Beria. Linking us. Me, my family. Do you know what sort of man he is?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He’s releasing people from prison...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Releasing people was my idea! He rapes children! Did you know that? He's murdered millions.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Have you?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Have I what?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Raped children, murdered millions?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I do not rape children! (pauses, agitated) I am not Beria! I have... stood up against our enemies. I have been relentless in my defence of the nation and the party. And I have hated doing what I had to do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hated it. But Beria loves every minute. I'm the reformer, not him! (trying to calm down) Why did you write that note?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Stalin killed my parents, my friends, Zinaida Reich, Kuperchinski.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: You were friends with Kuperchinski? Christ! Anyone else?! He's furious. Maria tries to hide her fear.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Rovik perhaps? We were friends.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Rovik?! How the fuck are you even still alive?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Comrade. Nikita Sergeyevich, you know me, I...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: No I don’t know you. Don’t say I know you. But now Beria ties me to you, and you know how this works. They kill your parents, then your sister. And brother. And friends....

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes. I know how you all work. For a beat it feels like Khrushchev might slap her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparsely furnished. Vasily in vest and military trousers, practising his speech. Svetlana sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: My father was a warm and mighty bear...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: He was. He WAS...

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: That bear now lies cold. We, 170 million cubs, his weeping orphans. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 May 2016 Draft 10 97.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Russian cubs, Georgian cubs, Armenian cubs. Lithuanian cubs...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Do you list every nation?

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Should I not? There's a knock on the door. Beria comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: How’s my precious guest? Vasily looks at him flatly, clearly still mistrustful.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Thank you for looking after him.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Of course. (offers him a hip flask) I brought you something to calm your nerves. Vasily hesitates. Beria takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vasily, I'm your godfather. I would never poison you. I'd arrange a plane crash or something. (he laughs, they don't)

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Your jokes are always so.. clenched. Svetlana takes the flask from Vasily, gives it back to Be Vasily’s about to protest but Svetlana’s firm.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (to Vasily, at Beria) We agreed we would be presentable at the reception. Vasily sulkily agrees.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: I hate being sober. It’s a terrible, terrible mood to be in. She kisses him and leaves with Beria, who’s impressed.  145 146 20 May 2016 Draft 10 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUOUS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria and Svetlana come out of the room and shut the door They walk away, leaving an NKVD MAN on guard.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (indicates speech) Going to “reaffirm” your father’s contract with the people. New rights. New liberties...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Why does everything have to be “new”? They go through into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUOUS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A comfortable living room - the nicest we've seen. Firepl rug, souvenirs and gifts all over. On a table, a massive is open.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: ..."new” potatoes...”new” Spring Fashions...”new”... Beria hands Svetlana a long, long list from the file, indicates an entry.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Yuri's dead. March 15th, 1949. Attempted escape from Kolyma with twelve others. Executed. I’m Sorry... Svetlana bursts into tears, crumples.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: But... you said you'd bring him back. You...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: It wasn't possible...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: You lied to me!...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: It was outside my jurisdiction. He indicates the list. Vasily suddenly enters the room, looking for the flask.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 99.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: My mind’s going everywhere, like a million clarinets! I need... He’s spotted the flask. Svetlana, furious, grabs it as Be silently signals to the NKVD Man to escort Vasily back in the room and lock the door. Vasily miserably complies.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (ignoring Vasily, and reading the letter) Signed by the entire Committee.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Sit down, Svetlana.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I’d prefer to...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (kind, forceful) Sit down. Svetlana refuses. She’s angry, scared, defiant, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had to do some terrible things for the Union. Your father said: Always look in the distance, never at the mud and blood at your feet. But, Svetlana, if Yuri were alive today I’d be releasing him.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: So you’re saying, all that... (indicates list) ..-killing was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (impatient) Many lies were told. Evidence was fabricated. Those responsible will be found and...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Shot? This killing machine is never going to stop, is it?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Grow up, Svetlana! The world out there is full of dangerous men in uniforms and dinner suits. I’m offering you and that...gabbling bowl of moonshine my protection.  147 20 May 2016 Draft 10 100.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: We are not children! (rethinks ) I am not a child!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Oh you are. And I warn you, Svetlana. Stay by my side. Or you'll both be beaten inside out and strung up for the crows. By the others.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Why should I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Because I’m the only one who’s telling you - trust no-one else.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Can I keep this?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Of course. Svetlana, I am so very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: You're just like my father. She kisses him tenderly on the cheek and leaves. He goes to a hidden DOOR and unlocks it. Goes up some dar and dusty stairs, to a small room. We see a mattress, a v with flowers, and an awkward teenage girl, crying. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Oh no. I’m here to cheer you up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall of noise. And bodies. It's the end of a dinner. Th dignitaries have broken into groups to smoke, drink and c Maria’s playing Chopin. We’re with Khrushchev as he weave his way round. Zhukhov is regaling DIGNITARIES with a war story.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: The greatest enemy any soldier has to face? It’s not guns, or fear, or hunger. It's chafing... Svetlana is with Vasily who's smartened up and sobered up She scans the room.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 101.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: I’ve made enemies of everyone here. Oh Christ, sober’s HARD.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (encouraging) You're doing well. I almost believe that smile.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: It’s easy. All I have to do is say hello, shake their hands, and not call them cunts. The HUNGARIAN PRESIDENT comes up to them, shakes hands. Vasily’s about to say something... We’re now with Beria as he enters the room, creating a gravitational pull. Back with Vasily and Svetlana.

dialogues.speaker: HUNGARIAN PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: All of Hungary sends you our deepest condolences. Anything you want from us, just ask.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Vasily, anything you want from Hungary?

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: A horse, I would like. Big horse. Khrushchev comes into the room and looks around. DELOV co up to him with a spotty, awkward TEENAGE GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: DELOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Minister. I've found her. Khrushchev looks at her, full of contempt.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: She's too big! She looks like a baby giraffe fell down some stairs. Delov takes her away. Kaganovich and Bulganin join Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Heard you were “canoodling” with the pianist?

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, she give it plenty of left hand, Nicky?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 102.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Did she sit on your Presidium?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (ignoring them) This is classic Beria. Nail the woman as a spy, link her to the man, nail the man. I need someone with an army. Now! Svetlana spots Mikoyan. He tries to avoid her gaze, but s insistent.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Comrade Sickle! You look very dashing tonight!

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: (disdaining Vasily) Thank you. I hope your brother isn’t armed this evening...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: He’s not even loaded!

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Fuck me! Mikoyan pretends he’s being called away. He's off.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “He’s not even loaded”?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (joining Zhukhov) Comrade Field Marshall. A word?

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: I’m in the middle of a... Khrushchev steering Zhukhov to a door.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Zhukhov’s companions) He either planted the flag on Hitler’s bunker, or knocked the bear out with one punch. (to Zhukhov) There’s an urgent military matter. He guides him away.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Bloody rude, actually, Nicky. It wasn't Hitler's bunker, it was Goebbels’. And it genuinely happened.  148 20 May 2016 Draft 10 103. They pass Bulganin, who’s a little agitated.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Nicky? They say the streets are heaving with people... Zhukhov and Khrushchev exchange a glance. Back with Svetlana and Vasily. Molotov approaches, his arms reaching out.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Here’s Molotov. A hundred rubles says he calls us ‘comrades’ then hugs us.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (to Svetlana and Vasily) Comrades!

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: (sotto) I’m not kissing him. Khrushchev steering Zhukhov to out the doorway of the mai reception and across the large stairway.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (conspiratorial) Could I count on you if someone we both know was out of control, dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (sotto) Yes! Wanted to deal with him for bloody ages. I'm in. Khrushchev shows them into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev and Zhukhov are alone.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (that was easy) Really? Good. Because he's planning a coup.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: What? Come on, Nicky. He’s so pissed all the time he can’t tell his arse from his windpipe. Khrushchev pauses.  20 May 2016 Vasily? A beat. Draft 10 104.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We ARE talking about the same person. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beria.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Beria? Well, someone's grown balls the size of Kremlin domes. Yes, bravo. Bloody Beria. How DARE that hookworm try to out-manouevre the army!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: He wants to hijack my reforms, make the people love him...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: The people are a pendulum of idiots. They can be made to hate him... (clicks fingers) Like that. But listen, Nicky... (closer) I’ve got the soldiers. What have you got..?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: All I’ve got is the funeral, and flowers and fucking trains. Khrushchev picks up a phone.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (down the phone) Get me the Transport Minister... Zhukhov slamming doors, opening cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: You’d think there’d be vodka. Even beancounters drink vodka...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (shushing him) Double the train services into Moscow. He hangs up. They head back the stairway to the reception.  149 20 May 2016 Draft 10 105.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Moscow’s full already. It’1ll be total bloody chaos. Well played, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I'm the peacemaker round here and I'll fuck up anyone who gets in my way!

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Cock the size of an atomic bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria at the piano, playing. Beria leans in and whispers, cleaning his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: So what does Nikita taste like? I assume it's shitty traitor, like you. What do YOU taste of, I wonder? She stops playing. Dramatic silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I will carry on if you step away from the piano.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (innocent, to the room) I always thought that piece ended in an odd place! Beria steps back from Maria and she carries on playing. Malenkov is with Delov and a LITTLE GIRL who looks very l the one from the picture.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Smile, sweetheart. The girl reveals terrible teeth. MALENKOV (CONT’D) With your mouth shut? (off her closed mouth) Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Now I must take my dog out. For an evacuation! Perhaps two! Molotov leaves.  150 20 May 2016 Draft 10 106.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (you're the biggest) When this is over, go home and drink vodka until you pass out. I never want to see you sober again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut from street to street, and see them fill with peop Wider shots reveal them coming in all directions. Hordes people on narrow streets, getting very crowded. An NKVD colonel, ENTIN is having a quiet cigarette. He lo up. At the end of the street, the crowd are heading towar him. He's on a barricade made of trucks and armoured cars with turrets, manned by about 20 NKVD SOLDIERS. Entin motions for the loudhailer. It's passed to him. He addresses the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIN
dialogues.text: Halt! This is a secure area! Return to your homes, comrades! Now! The crowd hesitate but don't stop. Some hold images of Stalin.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shouts ) We've come to see Comrade Stalin. Others in the crowd roar approval.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIN
dialogues.text: Please, stop! Or we will have to open fire! They're still coming. The streets are jammed, heaving. Pe straining, crying, children being passed over heads.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to his soldiers) On my order, fire over their heads. The soldiers take aim. One of them shoots in panic. Panic in the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have not given the command! Shrieking. Bodies being lifted. Some pick up rocks and st from the street.  151 20 May 2016 Draft 10 107.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Disperse! Go back!... The crowd begin to advance. Entin draws his revolver. People start throwing rocks. One hits Entin. He staggers back, bleeding. The crowd is almost upon them.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE
dialogues.text: The soldiers and machine guns fire. The soldiers reload a keep firing, panicking. The screams of the crowd mix with the terrifying gunshots

dialogues.speaker: CEASE FIRE
dialogues.text: It stops. Entin stares out, horrified. His POV: piles of bodies, mostly dead, some wounded: men, women, children.

dialogues.speaker: BEING INSTRUCTED TO HANDLE THE SITUATION.
dialogues.text: Beria approaches Malenkov, followed closely by Khrushchev Malenkov is practicing for the photo, holding the girl up

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (through smile) That moron put the trains back on. Rioting crowds. Fifteen hundred dead.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: (putting the girl down) No, you're too heavy. She’s put down and taken away.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Beria’s men fired on the crowds. He’s out of control, Georgy, I...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Khrushchev) What’s between your ears? Sausage?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 108.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Oh, I think I know who the people will blame. (indicates self) The poor old shitsack in charge...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Georgy, look...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Delov, bring the girl back. I need to make an appearance.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Perhaps the army should be in charge of the railway stations. Delov brings the girl back as Zhukhov arrives.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Bit late now, eh Beria?

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: They were outside Moscow, on his orders!

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: My orders? They were... (points with girl’s hand) «..your orders! And starting the trains... (pointing at Khrushchev) ...-were his orders!

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: So, what are YOU going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: (to girl) What do you think, darling? You're the only one making any sense. They all gradually edge out the room to a quieter spot by staircase.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Someone is going to have to be the face of this fucking travesty.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: That's easy: Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You ordered the trains!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 109.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: And your men shot the people getting off them.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: He does have a point.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: No he doesn’t. There is no point to Nikita Khrushchev. Malenkov signals - The girl is taken away again.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: We should blame the security forces. Hothead officers on the ground...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) God Almighty, can you THINK? Or can you only pose for portraits? I. Am. Security. You... (mimicking Malenkov’s open- mouthed surprise) -.-baked cod in a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Oh, says the fucking jellied eel...

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Let’s all calm down. (to Malenkov) Even if you DO get blamed. We close ranks. We rehabilitate you, we...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Yes, it's the new Soviet Union now...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: For the good of the party I ask...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You spineless rat! Fuck you! You’re just a bloated corpse we propped up and stuck in a fancy uniform. (to the room) You want to blame me? It's time all of you realised who kept the daggers out of your fucking backs! Show some fucking respect! I have documents on all of you. ALL OF

dialogues.speaker: YOU
dialogues.text: (to Khrushchev) 13th March, 1937. Zolotov trials. 42 dead, 173 exiled. Your signature. 5th October 1946. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 May 2016 Draft 10 110.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Katzenelson. 63 executed, 219 exiled. Your signature...

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Beria. Enough.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to Kaganovich) Radek, Skrypny, your own brother. Your signature... He gestures at Khrushchev, Kaganovich, Bulganin and Mikoy Malenkov is stood behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of you! I've seen what you've done. It’s a very! Fucking! Long! List! He scatters some papers on the floor. Silence. The commit stare at the papers.

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: (heading off) I think I saw some brandy out here...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Lavrentiy. We can put this right.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (calming down) We'll meet straight after the funeral tomorrow. We will find out who's properly to blame for this. Arraign the officers who fired. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Of course. Beria heads down the stairs. The others stand there, still stunned from Beria's outbur

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can just demote him. Make him Minister Responsible for Fisheries or something.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Do you know what you’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: He's using you, Georgy. He'll use you and then he'll kill you. You saw those papers.  152 153 20 May 2016 Draft 10 111.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: He pointed at you, not me.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: He said “all of you”.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I was behind him. He went (gestures) “all of you”.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: "All of you".

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: No. "All of you".

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: (demonstrates ) He said: "All of you".

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: All of YOU can kiss MY arse! Get mme the girl, I’m going onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malenkov steps onto a balcony with the girl. Because he doesn’t lift her up, we can hardly see her.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Two cars parked, with their drivers some distance away. Kaganovich and Khrushchev lean against one of the cars.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Who will the people blame? Me or Beria? Who looks like he’s got blood on his boots?

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: (you? ) Oh, Beria. People will definitely blame Beria.

dialogues.speaker: MURDERER
dialogues.text: Molotov approaches on foot, with a small dog.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 112. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) You've killed hundreds, Nicky! You certainly got your big funeral!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I regret this already...

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Can’t talk. Get in the car. Khrushchev and Kaganovich share a look - then get in. Molotov pulls his dog in too.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: (RE dog) I see she moults. Molotov takes out a cuddly toy. The dog starts barking - loud, irritating - and jumping up, trying to grab it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: This- (waves the cuddly toy again, to more barks) -is for any hungry ears...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: The car isn’t bugged. We'd see wires stretching to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (looks out) The drivers. So... (close, menacing) Let’s do him in.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (vigorously shakes the toy) Beria. The treacherous snake brought back the Bishops. And he brought back Polina. He expressly ignored Stalin’s orders. The man has no soul. He ordered his men to open fire. Genius, Nicky.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 113.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (just about keeping up with Molotov’s logic) Yes, Beria’s the murderer here...

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Those who were killed must not die in vain...

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: This is how the Soviet Union was built. Not with Bishops. Today, Beria gets an eight-foot crucifix up his arse! The dog's still yapping.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: I've had nightmares that make more sense than this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: The people who died are martyrs. You have to do it in... The dog has stopped barking. Molotov waves the toy again it jumps and barks.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Please. Can this fucking DOG be a martyr?

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: You have to do it in one go. Bang! Like in '36. Won't be easy though.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Zhukhov’s already got the army sharpening their bayonets...

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: And it’s got to be today. Only time the army’s in the capital.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Excellent. I’m in!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Good, good. We have a majority!

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: You two, me, Bulganin...  154 20 May 2016 Draft 10 114.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (cuts in) You need Malenkov and Mikoyan too.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: But... why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: It's what Stalin would have wanted. The Committee, as one! Act fast Comrade. Act fast or be dead. (to dog) YES. Uncle Nicky’s going to be dead if he doesn’t get a move on, isn’t he? Oh yes he is. Yes he is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee, dignitaries, generals, Svetlana, Mezhnikov Kobulov wait in formal dress. The guarded coffin is nearb Khrushchev watches uneasily as Malenkov jokes with Beria. Svetlana comes close.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: You promised to protect me and my family...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Of course. Always, my dearest most precious...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: Well you didn’t. She slips him the piece of paper Beria gave her, leaves. Beria and Zhukhov appear, surprising Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: So. Comrade Zhukhov and I have been conferring... Khrushchev looks appalled. Has he been betrayed?

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: All chums again now, eh? Onward!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: He's come up with a plan for Vasily's speech.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: It will go ahead but it “may” coincide with the fly-past.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 115.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (flooded with relief) Hah! Excellent! That’s an excellent idea! Zhukhov! The genius!

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Let's give the old maniac the send- off he deserves. A general sense of bonhomie. Beria puts his hand on Khrushchev - it's a reconciliation. He then pats Khrushch trousers... Bang, it’s the tomato game again. Zhukhov finds it funny.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s what he would have wanted. Kobulov gestures to Beria who goes over to him, leaving Malenkov with Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Georgy... A 21-gun salute begins outside - the signal for the funer

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have to act today.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Let’s bury the old man first. Khrushchev is about to reply but is interrupted by Mezhni

dialogues.speaker: MEZHNIKOV
dialogues.text: Comrades! Please take your places for the cortege. Khrushchev and his allies take their places around the coffin. Beria and Malenkov are at the front, next to Khrushchev. Zhukhov is directly behind him.
Malenkov joins in, as before, expecting Zhukhov to allow to command the moment.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Lift!

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yes, lift, everyone.  155 156 20 May 2016 Draft 10 116. Everyone lifts and tries to get comfortable. Some have a shoulder under it, others just a hand. They start walking coffin forward towards the open door as a cannon fires ev few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Georgy! Georgy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUOUS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shuffle out into a solemn Red Square, packed with mourners. Zhukhov still pressing Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Is Malenkov on board?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Georgy’s in. One hundred per cent.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: All or nothing now, Nicky, eh? They are now in full view of the crowd. The pall-bearers shift the coffin on into the mausoleum, helped by some SOLDIERS. Zhukhov takes a step back and salutes. We see an extreme long shot of Zhukhov saluting. His eyes flick upwards. He knows he's being watched. A colonel with bushy eyebrows - BREZHNEV, on a Red Square rooftop, puts down his binoculars. Khrushchev nods at Bulganin and Kaganovich: it's happenin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balcony on top of Lenin's mausoleum. The committee members and dignitaries are stood in a line.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (struggling, in tears) Stalin's love of ...love of the nation... The people's pain... The pain of the people... Oh... We pan along legs. Chalk marks - initials of who's to sta where. A technician crouches out of view. Khrushchev's fo scratches an itch on his calf.  157 158 159 160 161 20 May 2016 Draft 10 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brezhnev and MOSKALENKO walk with briefcases towards some NKVD MEN by a set of double doors. An NKVD lieutenant, Pervak salutes them. They show papers, hand over pistols, inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malenkov’s delivery is incredibly dull.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yet we will draw strength from the continuity of the revolution as it goes on an on, generation after generation... yet today we pause in grief, and sorrow. But is not a pause in itself part of the revolution...? Beria looks bored. Others sway to keep warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures of Stalin and Lenin. Brezhnev closes the door. B men open up their briefcases to reveal wires, a small red light bulb, electrical equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vasily is now at the microphone. He shouts into it.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: My father was a great social scientist! But we, the people of the Soviet Union, are not laboratory animals! No! We are laboratory technicians! The very noisy fly-over begins. He tries to shout over it

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father! Your father! Our father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moskalenko fixes the lightbulb to a window frame. Brezhne trails a wire along the edge of the skirting board toward set of double-doors into a larger meeting room, with chai around a long oak table.  162 163 164 165 166 167 20 May 2016 Draft 10 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria speaking, Malenkov and Khrushchev on either side.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: We must embrace our terrible loss with the strength and love for our nation that Stalin himself..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moskalenko hammers a wedge into the window frame, checks jammed shut, as NKVD GUARDS listen to Beria's speech in a courtyard outside, their backs to the window. Brezhnev fastens a button underneath the table, checks a leading down the table leg and under the carpet. He puts place card - “Comrade General Secretary Malenkov" at the of the table, where the button is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria continues his speech.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: We now carry forward the torch of revolution. I applaud the Central Committee, who have declared Georgy Maximilianovich Malenkov President and General Secretary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brezhnev presses the button under the table. Moskalenko i the red bulb. It lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee members are feeling the cold.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: .-We promise you rights and liberties, bread and peace. Everyone in the crowd applauds. A bit too much for Malenk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The view from the balcony of Red Square - the applauding crowd, the flags, the banners and portraits.  168 169 170 20 May 2016 Draft 10 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria walks cheerfully with Molotov, followed by the PRESIDIUM MEMBERS, Zhukhov - in army greatcoat - then Khrushchev and Malenkov.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: "Bread and peace". I knew it would work. It was between "peace" and "sausages". The generals and ZHUKHOV reach the NKVD guards at the doo

dialogues.speaker: PERVAK
dialogues.text: Forgive me, comrades. Your weapons.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I think we can rely on the liberators of Berlin to use their weapons appropriately. Khrushchev peels off.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just going to freshen my trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev heads into the toilet. Brezhnev and his men ar all there, waiting quietly. Nobody says anything. Khrushchev pulls out Svetlana’s Yuri note, soiled with tomato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khrushchev catches up with Malenkov in the corridor ahead the meeting room. Khrushchev discreetly hands Malenkov Svetlana's note.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Beria gave this to Svetlana. Let her know what you did to Zhednov. See? He’d shit on all of us. Malenkov grows pale. He quickly puts the paper in his poc

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: The snake. Alright.  171 172 20 May 2016 Draft 10 120.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I'll bring up the emergency motion. There's a button under the desk at your end. You hit it. Yes? Malenkov nods, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Yes. But just a demotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zhukhov enters the toilet. Opens his coat to reveal Kalashnikovs. Brezhnev smiles. A presidium member walks i go to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDIUM MEMBER
dialogues.text: I didn’t do any... A hand is clamped over the Presidium member's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malenkov is at the head of the table, Beria near the wind Outside, some NKVD GUARDS patrol the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Malenkov. Malenkov looks at him, unable to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's start. (still nothing. He takes over) SHALL WE? Item One. The unfortunate events of yesterday evening... Khrushchev raises his hand. Malenkov doesn't acknowledge

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is clear that the regrettable deaths of many citizens hastening to the capital... Khrushchev thrusts his hand even higher, glares at Malenk

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-had several local causes...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Er, Comrade Khrushchev has the floor... Beria, perplexed, looks at Malenkov, who avoids his gaze.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 121.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Comrades, I propose a new Agenda Item One. “The conduct of Comrade Beria”.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Can anyone else hear that barking dog? I’ve lost my thread now... Malenkov just stares at the table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: I accuse Comrade Beria of centralising power within his Ministry at the expense of the Party and the Central Committee. Of betraying the Soviet Union to capitalist interests...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (to everyone) I warn you, Nicky. This petulant Wild West stuff will end very badly.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (indicating button) Georgy! Georgy! Malenkov just stares forward, unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Comrades, Perhaps there is concern at the speed of our reforms. But really, THIS nonsense? Khrushchev leaps up, rushes round to the button and hits hard, knocking Malenkov out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Arrest this madman! He’s out of control!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red light bulb lights up.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Good luck, ladies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers burst into the room, led by Zhukhov.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Hands in the air!  175 176 177 20 May 2016 Draft 10 122. Beria puts the palm of his hand on the window. The NKVD guards are too far away to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Beria’s palm, he's written: "ALERT".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zhukhov points his weapon at Beria.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Hands in the air or bullet in the fucking face! Malenkov’s hands go up. Khrushchev slaps them down in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (banging on window) GUARDS!!... Zhukhov hits him in the face with his rifle butt. Beria d to the ground, his pince-nez fly off. Zhukhov gets in clo

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: See? You want a job done properly, send for the army. He frisks Beria. The other soldiers keep their guns on hi

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: He's got a knife by his ankle. Beria stares at Malenkov, who starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria is handcuffed on a chair, his face a bloodied mess.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Georgy... Malenkov, sat across the room, looks ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (to Malenkov) Say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Remove his belt. It's hard for a man to escape when his trousers are falling down.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 123.

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Leave the man some dignity, please. That suit without a belt would be a disaster!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, rest assured I sense the strength of feeling in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Shut up, you fucking tumour.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: That man is responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocents...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: We all are...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Exactly. Collective guilt.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Comrades, please...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: What happens now? Zhukhov mimes shooting Beria.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Zhukhov! (to Malenkov) We wait for Red Square to empty of NKVD...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Then I give the signal and we roll this barrel of shit out. The doors burst open. It's Kobulov and 2 NKVD lieutenants Pervak, armed and carrying trays of sandwiches and cold meats. They freeze. Everyone turns and looks at them. Zhukhov cl his hand over Beria’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: KOBULOV
dialogues.text: Sorry, comrades. Wrong room. They turn to go. Beria tries to call after them.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: Those sandwiches were curling up anyway. (to Beria) Your lot can’t even do CATERING. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to room) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several trucks and armoured cars drive up. Soldiers leap and surround the NKVD, who raise their weapons. An army COLONEL walks over to an NKVD OFFICER. The NKVD officer gestures for the NKVD to lower their guns. The colonel hurries inside, followed by his men, guns coc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The middle-aged man arrested earlier is playing chess wit his son. All is forgiven. The NKVD burst in.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: No! NO! He didn't mean anything! The NKVD march over to the son, grab him and head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonel and his men walk through. Kobulov spots them. Dives into a store-cupboard. The men head in after him. W hear shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vasily lies on the bed in his ceremonial uniform, drinkin The door is opened by an NKVD OFFICER, who steps to one s An army GENERAL, a CAPTAIN and two SOLDIERS enter. The soldiers aim their rifles at Vasily.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: No! NO! You can't!... The general fires his pistol into the wall by Vasily's he

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You nearly fucking killed me and now I’m DEAF! You hear me, I’m

dialogues.speaker: DEAF
dialogues.text: The captain hauls Vasily up, tears off his epaulets, his medals, buttons. He's been disgraced. They drag him out.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am? Do you know who YOU are? Who the fuck are you?  182 183 20 May 2016 Draft 10 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some NKVD OFFICERS and Beria's terrified STAFF are being marched out at gunpoint by a group of soldiers. Vasily's dragged into the living room. The frightened teenage girl is hauled out of the hidden r MARIA is also taken out of another locked room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zhukhov peeks through the curtains. The NKVD have been replaced by Red Army SOLDIERS. Zhukhov moves across to Be and stands him up. Takes off his belt.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: OK, Judy Garland. Let’s go. He hauls him forward. Beria's trousers start to fall. Brezhnev pulls them up for him and Beria grabs them.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: If we could discuss this rationally...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (that’s a good idea) You're right. We should... (gags Beria) “Ooh, what's happening? My trousers are round my ankles but my cock’s not inside an orphan...” One of the newly-arrived soldiers hands Zhukhov a sack. H puts it over Beria's head.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Hey! Nicky! We agreed. A demotion.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s definitely THAT, wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Remember when you took Polina away? How you must have enjoyed it. I’m certainly enjoying this, you cockroach. Beria struggles. Zhukhov punches him in the gut. He folds is held up by Moskalenko and Brezhnev. His trousers fall. Brezhnev pulls up Beria's trousers, puts them in his hand  20 May 2016 Draft 10 126.

dialogues.speaker: BREZHNEV
dialogues.text: Hold them!...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (taunting Beria) How’s the meeting going, would you say, COMRADE SACK? You're on a list now, fucker!

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: Stop this!...

dialogues.speaker: I'M THE REFORMER
dialogues.text: Beria is led out the room, battling with his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Roudenko is in the basement, along with Konev...

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: You're putting him on trial? Now? I'm disgusted! And slightly impressed at your efficiency, Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: This is all totally, totally, beyond any agenda...

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: Listen to yourself. What do you think is happening here, Georgy? Should someone be taking minutes?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: We have to act instantly... Molotov bangs the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Bang! Over! Marxism-Leninism was born in flames! Let the fire of our vengeance consume all traitors and bastards!

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: No! I forbid it!...

dialogues.speaker: MIKOYAN
dialogues.text: You want the NKVD to spring him from jail? Things’d get a bit lively then...

dialogues.speaker: BULGANIN
dialogues.text: Nobody wants civil war.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 127.

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: He will kill us all... Khrushchev tries to hand Malenkov a document.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Come on Georgy. Sign this or we're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: He deserves a trial! The man deserves a trial!...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (furious) What about Tukhachevsky and Piatakov and Meyerhold and Mikhoels? Didn't they deserve a trial? And poor Sokolnikov. Who begged him to look after his elderly mother. That monster strangled her in front of him. I’ve killed a lot of people. I did it because it was my duty. That human turd killed for pleasure. Khrushchev puts a brotherly hand on Malenkov’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Georgy, we’ve gone too far now. The only choice we have is between his death or his revenge. Malenkov looks at him, pale and dazed.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: I'm General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: That's right. You are. He hands him the document and a pen. Malenkov signs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance we see the generals and Brezhnev dragging Beria. His trousers fall and he trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleak space. An improvised courtroom. On a raised stage: ROUDENKO, mid-40s in a judge's gown. N to him, Marshall KONEV.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 128. The Presidium and Committee members are there with senior PARTY AND MILITARY OFFICIALS. Armed SOLDIERS everywhere. Zhukhov, Moskalenko and Brezhnev walk Beria to the improv dock. Zhukhov removes the sack and gag.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You are all witnesses to a criminal travesty! Think what you like! You are STILL witnesses! Konev keeps banging.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I demand my rights under, under... article 43 of the... Stop banging, I demand to be heard! We are not savages!

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: YOU are! YOU are!

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: (weakening, to Malenkov) Georgy... Our wives... what will you tell your wife? And mine? The children?

dialogues.speaker: KONEV
dialogues.text: Comrade General Secretary... Trembling, Malenkov looks to Khrushchev who nods. Malenko tries to read out a statement.

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: "Lavrenti Pavolovich Beria...'

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: You fucking traitor...

dialogues.speaker: MALENKOV
dialogues.text: "Lavrenti Pavlovich Beria. You are accused..." Malenkov stops. He looks like he's going to faint.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV BERIA
dialogues.text: Fucks sake! (at same time) (taking the document) I am a Marshall of the Soviet "You are accused of using Union, a member of... your position as Minister of the Interior to plot against the Soviet Union with the goal of forwarding the interests of foreign powers..."  20 May 2016 Draft 10 129.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Foreign powers! Which ones? The fucking MOON?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (over Beria) "You are also accused of 347 counts of rape, of sexual deviancy and bourgeois immorality, of acts of perversion with children as young as 7 years old...

dialogues.speaker: BERIA
dialogues.text: Ah. Everyone in this ROOM is responsible for someone’s death. So let's find something exotic for old Beria. Beria stops protesting, completely knocked. He spots Svetlana, her eyes full of hate.

dialogues.speaker: BERIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Svetushka...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (reading as quickly as he can) .--including the rapes of Luba Dolomaya, aged 12, Petra Nikova, 13

dialogues.speaker: ERROR
dialogues.text: Khrushchev skips ahead, trying to shout over Beria.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Anna Laranskaya, Nadia Ranova...etc etc... Magya Holovic...treason... anti-Soviet behaviour...er, the court finds you guilty and sentences you to be taken to Lubyanka prison and shot...

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (whispers to Beria) Shut it. Look, here’s “Exhibit A”. Beria looks down. Zhukhov is holding a knife to his ribs. Beria suddenly loses it, starts screaming like a little g Khrushchev calmly waves goodbye.  186 187 20 May 2016 Draft 10 130. Zhukhov, Brezhnev and some soldiers drag him outside. Cha are knocked over, there are screams and shouts. It's chao They've got Beria as far as the doorway. A shot rings out Then another. More screams. A burst of sub-machine-gun fi A shout of "CEASE-FIRE!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria's body is in the doorway of the courtroom. He's rid with bullets, bleeding heavily. Svetlana spits on the body.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: For Yuri. For my mother. Zhukhov reaches into Beria's mouth and pulls out a tooth.

dialogues.speaker: ZHUKHOV
dialogues.text: (off their looks) Nearly a full set now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beria’s body is hauled out by SOLDIERS. They dump it unceremoniously, douse it with petrol and set fire to it. Everyone emerges from the building, registering the burni corpse with varying levels of coolness. They’ve seen some brutal things. But Svetlana is shocked, and moves away from the group. S looks like she may throw up. Khrushchev is now the centre of gravity. Everyone wants t in orbit around him. Grim wordless exchanges. Kaganovich close

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Now we can turn the corner. Put the bloodshed behind us. ANGLE on Malenkov. He looks bereaved.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I worry about Malenkov though. Can we trust him?

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Can you ever trust a weak man? Khrushchev agrees. They can’t. He spots Svetlana, walks o to her. Kaganovich acting as informal bouncer, keeping everyone else away.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 131.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: There’s no need.

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I don’t know where...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Vasily’s safe. I give you my word, Svetlana, I will look after him. He hands her an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here is your passage to safety, too...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: (re envelope contents) Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Vasily must stay. For his own safety. We can’t have a drunken madman spreading conspiracy theories all over the world...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I could...

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: No. He stays. You must go, for YOUR sake. There will be a reckoning here. Your...story may not fit. One of these men might have to kill you... She’s shocked. Khrushchev needs her to look at him. She d

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I might have to kill you. A stunned beat. Her bitter smile. She looks at Malenkov, Mikoyan, Bulganin...

dialogues.speaker: SVETLANA
dialogues.text: I never thought it would be you.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: Safe travels, Svetlana. A bow, he rejoins the group. Someone has produced vodka. corpse burns on.  188 20 May 2016 Draft 10 132.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we can turn the corner. Put the bloodshed behind us. They place a large electric fan next to the bin.

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I worry about Malenkov though. Can we trust him?

dialogues.speaker: KAGANOVICH
dialogues.text: Can you ever trust a weak man?

dialogues.speaker: KHRUSHCHEV
dialogues.text: (nods agreement) No... He turns the fan on and tips the ashes out. We watch the ashes dispel in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria is playing a Mozart piano concerto.

dialogues.speaker: COMMITTEE, INCLUDING MOLOTOV AND MALENKOV
dialogues.text: We pan up to a box, where we see Khrushchev smiling, in h element. Nina and some sycophants sit around him. We see Andreyev and Sergei in the control room. Something suggest Andreyev’s living in a new reality too - more anxious, surrounded by new equipment? Or more confident, bullying?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER IN CHIEF.
dialogues.text: We stay on Khrushchev smiling. A young Brezhnev is behind him.
